The "Honesty in Sweepstakes Act of 1999" prohibits the mailing of solicitations or offers that suggest recipients have won something of value when they have not. The "Honesty in Sweepstakes Act of 1999" prohibits mailing solicitations that falsely imply recipients have won something of value. Mail without the required notice may be disposed of as directed by the Postal Service. The notice must include a disclaimer about the nature of the game of chance or sweepstakes and the odds of winning. The Postal Service requires a standardized warning label on mailings related to games of chance or sweepstakes. The notice must be prominently displayed on the first page of the material and on any other enclosed pages. Envelopes and order entry devices must also bear the required notice. The Postal Service mandates a warning label on mailings for games of chance or sweepstakes, including those resembling negotiable instruments. If such material lacks the required notice, it will not be delivered and may be disposed of as directed by the Postal Service. Section 3005(a) of title 39, United States Code, is amended to include subsections (j) or (k). Section 3012 of title 39, United States Code, is also amended to impose civil penalties for mailing nonmailable materials. The amendment imposes civil penalties for mailing nonmailable materials, with varying amounts based on the number of pieces mailed. Congress suggests allocating collected penalties to increase consumer awareness of misleading solicitations received through the mail. The Honesty in Sweepstakes Act of 1999 prohibits preempting any State law regulating advertising or sales promotions involving the chance to win something of value.
